questions.text: Four days after undergoing a transradial amputation of the left forearm following a crush injury in a workplace accident, a 29-year-old man develops fever and hemodynamic instability. His postoperative course was uncomplicated. His current medications include morphine and enoxaparin. He has a central venous catheter inserted in his right femoral vein and a padded compressive dressing over the amputation stump. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 113/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 82/53 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Cardiopulmonary examinations shows no abnormalities. Examination of the amputation stump after removing the dressing shows erythema extending up to 1 cm around the surgical sutures but no induration, swelling, discharge, or crepitus. Purulent discharge and a fluctuant swelling are seen at the exit site of the femoral catheter. A swab of the purulent discharge is collected and blood samples are drawn simultaneously from the femoral central line and the right cubital fossa. Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric antimicrobial pharmacotherapy for this patient?

choices.text: Linezolid, ceftazidime, and gentamicin
Piperacillin-tazobactam
Vancomycin, cefepime, and caspofungin
Levofloxacin and metronidazole
Ampicillin and cefotaxime
Daptomycin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with linezolid, ceftazidime, and gentamicin is an acceptable empiric antibiotic regimen for ventilator-associated pneumonia. This patient, however, has no signs to suggest pneumonia; he most likely has a femoral CRBSI. Although linezolid provides coverage against gram-positive organisms (including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), and ceftazidime and gentamicin cover gram-negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas aeruginosa), empiric antimicrobial therapy for femoral CRBSI should also cover Candida spp.

B) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin-tazobactam provides coverage against gram-positive and gram-negative (including Pseudomonas aeruginosa) organisms, two of the most common types of pathogens that cause femoral CRBSI. However, piperacillin-tazobactam has no coverage against Candida spp. or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and is, therefore, not the best choice for this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Combination therapy with vancomycin, cefepime, and caspofungin is an appropriate empiric antimicrobial therapy for patients with a femoral CRBSI. As gram-positive organisms (coagulase-negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus, and enterococci) are the most common pathogens that cause CRBSI, gram-positive antibiotic coverage is warranted for all patients with CRBSI; vancomycin is usually recommended because of the high prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in health care settings. Compared to subclavian and jugular CRBSI, there is a higher risk of CRBSI caused by Candida spp. or gram-negative bacilli in femoral CRBSI due to the risk of colonization in this region. Therefore, gram-negative coverage (including for Pseudomonas aeruginosa) with a fourth-generation cephalosporin (e.g., cefepime) or a carbapenem as well as Candida spp. coverage with an echinocandin (e.g., caspofungin) is indicated. In patients with subclavian and jugular CRBSI, vancomycin alone is the most appropriate empiric therapy (see “Empiric antibiotic therapy for CRBSI” table).

Catheter removal is warranted in patients with sepsis and hemodynamic instability (such as this patient), endocarditis, suppurative thrombophlebitis, or persistent bacteremia despite > 72 hours of appropriate antimicrobial therapy against the causative pathogen. The catheter should also be removed in patients with CRBSI due to multi-drug resistant gram-negative bacteria, S. aureus, fungi, or mycobacteria.

D) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with levofloxacin and metronidazole is used as empiric antimicrobial therapy for surgical site infections in a clean-contaminated wound or a clean wound in the perineal region. This patient's wound, however, is considered a clean surgical wound and shows no signs of infection. This patient most likely has a femoral CRBSI, for which combination therapy with levofloxacin and metronidazole is not appropriate; although levofloxacin has gram-negative and partial gram-positive coverage, it does not cover methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Moreover, anaerobic bacteria, which metronidazole covers, are rarely implicated in CRBSI. Finally, empiric antimicrobial therapy for femoral CRBSI should also cover Candida spp.

E) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin and cefotaxime are used in the empiric treatment of neonatal meningitis. Although this regimen covers gram-positive and some gram-negative bacteria, it does not cover methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or Candida spp., all of which are common causative pathogens of femoral CRBSI.

F) INCORRECT:

Daptomycin provides coverage against gram-positive organisms, which are the most common causative pathogens of CRBSI. However, in patients with femoral CRBSI, gram-negative bacteria and Candida spp. should also be covered by empiric antimicrobial therapy. Daptomycin is only indicated for empirical gram-positive coverage in settings where vancomycin's minimum inhibitory concentration is > 2 μg/mL for the majority of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus isolates.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, hemodynamic instability, and purulent discharge and fluctuant swelling around the femoral catheter suggests a catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI). The location of the catheter is an important factor for determining appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Four days after an operation for a perforated gastric ulcer, a hospitalized 68-year-old woman develops decreased urinary output, hyperkalemia, and severe uremia. A tunneled central venous catheter is placed in the subclavian vein and renal replacement therapy is initiated. Ten days later, the patient develops fever and hypotension. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 86/50 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The skin overlying the catheter appears well perfused, with no tenderness to palpation and no purulent discharge. Samples for blood culture are drawn simultaneously from the central line and a peripheral vein. Blood cultures from the central line grow nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacilli. Three hours later, blood cultures from the peripheral venipuncture grow the same bacteria. Which of the following is the most effective measure to reduce the incidence of this patient's current infection?

choices.text: Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure in intensive care units
Implementation of real-time feedback loops for hand hygiene compliance
Placement of central venous catheters in the femoral rather than subclavian vein
Administration of ceftazidime through the introducer needle before passing the guide wire
Application of mupirocin ointment to the anterior nares of critically ill patients

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure is an example of an airborne precaution, which is effective in preventing in-hospital airborne transmission of diseases such as tuberculosis, measles, or varicella. P. aeruginosa is spread via contact transmission; standard precautions and contact precautions are effective in preventing nosocomial P. aeruginosa infections but airborne precautions are not. Moreover, in intensive care units, especially ones caring for immunosuppressed patients, a protective environment with a positive rather than negative ambient air pressure is usually maintained (neutropenic precautions).

B) CORRECT:

The most common mechanism for CLABSI is microbial spread (via surface motility and/or biofilm formation) to the CVC exit site from the patient's skin and/or the CVC hub. The hands of health care providers (HCPs) are often colonized by pathogens, resulting in HCPs cross-contaminating patients, other HCPs, and inanimate objects (leading to contact transmission), thereby facilitating nosocomial infections. Strict adherence to hand hygiene measures is necessary to prevent nosocomial infections such as CLABSI. Despite high numbers of hand hygiene stations and visual reminders at hospitals, the level of hand hygiene compliance among HCPs remains low because of lapses (due to work overload), poor situational awareness, and/or intolerance or aversion to certain disinfectants. An effective measure to increase compliance is a real-time feedback loop, in which hand hygiene observers or electronic hand hygiene systems monitor compliance and provide immediate feedback (e.g., verbal feedback on improper technique, data visualization of each hospital floor's hand hygiene process measures). Additional steps to increase hand hygiene compliance include staff training and providing alcohol-based foam rubs (which are quicker to use, more effective, and no more irritating to the skin than soap and water) at hand hygiene stations.

CLABSI bundles (a collection of measures to prevent CLABSI) include proper site identification and technique for CVC insertion (e.g., avoiding the femoral region whenever possible), standardized checklists, and aseptic precautions (e.g., sterile glove use, disinfection with chlorhexidine) for CVC insertion as well as CVC site care, CVC removal as soon as possible, and champions-led rounding. These measures are important adjuncts but not substitutes for hand hygiene.
Image Description:

Use the elbow to dispense disinfectant into the hand, then rub it with the other hand for ∼ 30 seconds. If the hands become dry before this time, dispense more disinfectant.

1. To cover palms, dorsal hands, and web spaces: palm-to-palm and dorsal hands-to-palm, both with fingers together and with fingers interlocked

2. To cover fingers and fingertips: dorsal fingers to opposite palm with fingers interlocked, and rotation of clasped fingers in opposite palm

3. To cover thumbs: rotation of thumb in opposite palm

C) INCORRECT:

When compared with the subclavian vein, placement of CVCs in the femoral vein has a lower risk of certain insertion-related complications (e.g., pneumothorax, hematomas, vein stenosis) but a higher risk of CLABSI. Moreover, femoral CVCs are more likely to result in CLABSIs with gram-negative bacilli and Candida because the groin area has high levels of colonization by these microbes (due to factors such as moisture in intertriginous areas and proximity to the anogenital region) and is harder to keep clean. Femoral CVCs should be avoided.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftazidime is an antibiotic that is effective against P. aeruginosa, and antibiotic lock therapy (e.g., with ceftazidime-heparin solutions) can be used selectively for the secondary prevention of CLABSI (e.g., for patients like this one receiving hemodialysis via tunneled catheters). However, antibiotics are ineffective in the primary prevention of CLABSI and do not have a role before or during CVC insertion (e.g., through the introducer needle). Antibiotics should only be used if indicated and, in such cases, the principle of antibiotic stewardship should be followed.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus, which causes nosocomial infections including CLABSI, often colonizes the anterior nares, and nasal application of mupirocin ointment is recommended for critically ill patients as part of the universal decolonization protocol to prevent methicillin-resistant S. aureus infection. However, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus whereas this patient has a P. aeruginosa infection. P. aeruginosa rarely colonizes the upper airways (e.g., in patients with cystic fibrosis) and mupirocin is typically ineffective against Pseudomonas spp.
questions.hint: The onset of fever and hemodynamic instability ≥ 48 hours after the insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) and the growth of the same organism on blood cultures from the CVC and a peripheral vein with a differential time to positivity ≥ 120 minutes indicate a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), even if the CVC's exit site does not show evidence of infection (e.g., tenderness, purulence). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacillus that causes CLABSI.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman with limited intravenous access develops a fever of 38.7°C while receiving hemodialysis. Her heart rate and blood pressure are normal. There is a clean-appearing tunneled hemodialysis catheter in the right internal jugular vein with no purulence at the exit site; the tunnel is not tender or fluctuant. There are no heart murmurs or stigmata of endocarditis. Blood cultures are drawn from the dialysis catheter and a peripheral vein. A single dose of vancomycin is administered.
Forty-eight hours later, the patient returns for her scheduled dialysis session. She remains afebrile with normal vital signs. The blood cultures drawn 2 days ago from the catheter and peripheral vein are now positive for coagulase-negative staphylococci. Repeat central and peripheral blood cultures are drawn and are negative.
The patient does not have an alternative site for dialysis catheter placement.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Remove the dialysis catheter, place a peripherally inserted central catheter, and treat with daptomycin
Retain the dialysis catheter and treat with vancomycin and antibiotic lock after each dialysis session for 10 days
Retain the dialysis catheter and observe
Retain the dialysis catheter and treat with vancomycin after each dialysis session for 4 weeks
Remove the dialysis catheter and order a transesophageal echocardiogram

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The dialysis catheter would need to be removed if the infection was caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or Candida species. A peripherally inserted central catheter is not appropriate because dialysis cannot be performed using a peripherally inserted central catheter.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with a suspected catheter-related bloodstream infection and a tunneled hemodialysis catheter should have blood cultures drawn from the catheter and from a peripheral vein. After blood culture collection, empiric treatment with antibiotics is indicated.

Patients with negative follow-up blood cultures should receive 10 to 14 days of intravenous antibiotics administered with antibiotic lock therapy (which involves installing a high concentration of an antibiotic in the catheter lumen) after each dialysis session. The dialysis catheter can be retained in stable patients with uncomplicated coagulase-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia.

A 10- to 14-day course of vancomycin is indicated in this scenario because this patient had prompt resolution of her symptoms with an intravenous antibiotic. Longer antimicrobial courses of 4 to 6 weeks are recommended with catheter removal when the patient has persistent symptoms, bacteremia or fungemia, or evidence of endocarditis or suppurative thrombophlebitis. Osteomyelitis also warrants a prolonged course.

The dialysis catheter would need to be removed if the infection was caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or Candida species.

Key learning point: The appropriate management for a stable patient receiving dialysis who has limited intravenous access and who develops coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia is to retain the dialysis catheter and treat with intravenous vancomycin.

C) INCORRECT:

The dialysis catheter can be retained in stable patients with uncomplicated coagulase-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia. However, after blood culture collection, empiric treatment with antibiotics is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

The dialysis catheter can be retained in stable patients with uncomplicated coagulase-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia. However, longer antimicrobial courses of 4 to 6 weeks are recommended with catheter removal when the patient has persistent symptoms, bacteremia, fungemia, or evidence of endocarditis or suppurative thrombophlebitis. Osteomyelitis also warrants a prolonged course.

E) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiogram would be indicated in patients with catheter-related bacteremia who have a prosthetic heart valve, pacemaker, implantable cardioverter-deﬁbrillator, or persistent bacteremia or fungemia. The dialysis catheter would need to be removed if the infection was caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or Candida species.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man who receives infliximab for treatment of severe psoriasis reports a one-week history of drainage from and increasing tenderness around his implanted port reservoir.
He is afebrile and appears well. There is a 2-cm by 2-cm area of erythema and induration over the subcutaneous pocket overlying the port. There is also tenderness and a small amount of seropurulent discharge with light palpation.
Cultures of the discharge are obtained, as are blood cultures. Gram stain of the discharge shows numerous pseudohyphae. Twelve hours after collection, both sets of blood cultures are growing yeast.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Remove the port and drain the abscess; additional antimicrobial therapy is not necessary
Retain the port and treat with intravenous antifungal therapy for 4 to 6 weeks
Remove the port, drain the abscess, and treat with intravenous antifungal therapy for 5 to 7 days
Retain the port and treat with intravenous antifungal therapy and topical ketoconazole cream for 21 days
Remove the port, drain the abscess, and start intravenous antifungal therapy; obtain serial blood cultures, and continue treatment until 14 days after the first negative culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In addition to having the port or catheter removed, all patients with candidemia should receive antifungal therapy for 14 days from the time of negative blood cultures and resolution of clinical signs and symptoms of candidal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravascular catheters, including implanted subcutaneous port reservoirs, should be removed in cases of catheter-related bloodstream infection due to Candida species.

C) INCORRECT:

In addition to having the port or catheter removed, all patients with candidemia should receive antifungal therapy for 14 days from the time of negative blood cultures and resolution of clinical signs and symptoms of candidal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravascular catheters, including implanted subcutaneous port reservoirs, should be removed in cases of catheter-related bloodstream infection due to Candida species.

E) CORRECT:

Intravascular catheters, including implanted subcutaneous port reservoirs, should be removed in cases of catheter-related bloodstream infection due to Candida species. If an abscess is evident at the exit site (or in the pocket of a port), debridement and drainage of the abscess is also required.

In addition to having the port or catheter removed, all patients with candidemia should receive antifungal therapy for 14 days from the time of negative blood cultures and resolution of clinical signs and symptoms of candidal infection.

Key learning point: The recommended treatment regimen for a patient with a port abscess and concomitant fungemia is removal of the port, incision and drainage of the abscess, and antifungal therapy for at least 14 days after the first negative blood culture.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman who is hospitalized for heart failure develops acute onset of fevers and chills one week after placement of a tunneled central venous catheter for long-term continuous dobutamine infusion.
Her temperature is 38.6°C, and she is newly hypotensive. Her catheter tunnel site appears unremarkable, and there is no change in her cardiovascular examination.
Blood cultures grow Escherichia coli resistant only to levofloxacin. Urinalysis and urine cultures are unremarkable.
Which one of the following therapies is optimal for this patient?

choices.text: Retain the central venous catheter; prescribe 28 days of meropenem plus antibiotic lock
Retain the central venous catheter; prescribe 14 days of ceftriaxone plus antibiotic lock
Retain the central venous catheter; prescribe 14 days of meropenem
Remove the central venous catheter; prescribe 28 days of meropenem
Remove the central venous catheter; prescribe 14 days of ceftriaxone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although catheter removal is preferred, catheters may sometimes need to be retained because of limited intravenous access. When the catheter cannot be removed safely, a trial of 10 to 14 days of intravenous antibiotic treatment with combined systemic and antibiotic lock therapy (the instillation of a high concentration of an antibiotic in the catheter lumen until the catheter's next use) is appropriate. Salvage should not be attempted if there is a tunnel infection or if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

Meropenem is a broad-spectrum agent that can potentially increase the risk for the emergence of multidrug-resistant organisms. In this case, ceftriaxone, a more narrow-spectrum agent, is preferred over meropenem. Typically, 28-day courses of an antibiotic regimen are recommended for infections with Staphylococcus aureus.

B) INCORRECT:

Although catheter removal is preferred, catheters may sometimes need to be retained because of limited intravenous access. When the catheter cannot be removed safely, a trial of 10 to 14 days of intravenous antibiotic treatment with combined systemic and antibiotic lock therapy (the instillation of a high concentration of an antibiotic in the catheter lumen until the catheter's next use) is appropriate. Salvage should not be attempted if there is a tunnel infection or if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

C) INCORRECT:

Although catheter removal is preferred, catheters may sometimes need to be retained because of limited intravenous access. When the catheter cannot be removed safely, a trial of 10 to 14 days of intravenous antibiotic treatment with combined systemic and antibiotic lock therapy (the instillation of a high concentration of an antibiotic in the catheter lumen until the catheter's next use) is appropriate. Salvage should not be attempted if there is a tunnel infection or if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

Meropenem is a broad-spectrum agent that can potentially increase the risk for the emergence of multidrug-resistant organisms. In this case, ceftriaxone, a more narrow-spectrum agent, is preferred over meropenem.

D) INCORRECT:

Although catheter removal is preferred, catheters may sometimes need to be retained because of limited intravenous access. When the catheter cannot be removed safely, a trial of 10 to 14 days of intravenous antibiotic treatment with combined systemic and antibiotic lock therapy (the instillation of a high concentration of an antibiotic in the catheter lumen until the catheter's next use) is appropriate. Salvage should not be attempted if there is a tunnel infection or if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

Meropenem is a broad-spectrum agent that can potentially increase the risk for the emergence of multidrug-resistant organisms. In this case, ceftriaxone, a more narrow-spectrum agent, is preferred over meropenem. Typically, 28-day courses of an antibiotic regimen are recommended for infections with Staphylococcus aureus.

E) CORRECT:

This patient developed a catheter-associated infection with a gram-negative organism and is hemodynamically unstable. The most appropriate treatment is to remove the catheter and prescribe systemic antibiotic therapy. The patient can continue receiving intravenous dobutamine through a peripheral line until blood cultures are sterile; at that point, a central venous catheter can be inserted if it is still needed.

If the patient has a rapid clinical and microbiologic response to the antibiotic therapy, the treatment should continue for 10 to 14 days. Because the organism in this scenario is resistant only to levofloxacin, therapy should be targeted using the most narrow-spectrum agent effective against the organism — in this case, ceftriaxone.

Key learning point: The optimal treatment for a hemodynamically unstable patient with a central venous catheter-associated infection caused by a gram-negative organism involves removing the catheter and prescribing appropriate systemic antibiotics for 7 to 14 days.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman develops a fever of 38.3°C four days after gastric bypass surgery for severe obesity. Her heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 128/88 mm Hg. She has mild incisional pain but no cough or dyspnea. She does not have any urinary symptoms and does not have a bladder catheter. She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
She has a central venous catheter on the right side of her neck, clear lung fields, and an obese, soft, nontender abdomen with decreased bowel sounds. Her incision is well approximated and without erythema, and her lower extremities have bilateral minimal edema under her serial compression devices.
Her leukocyte count is 8600 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000); a comprehensive metabolic profile is normal. She is tolerating a liquid diet without difficulty.
Blood cultures are drawn and are reported the next day as growing gram-positive cocci.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient's management?

choices.text: Remove the central venous catheter
Check a stool sample for Clostridioides difficile
Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast
Obtain an ultrasound of both lower extremities
Obtain CT of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Invasive devices, especially central venous catheters, should be removed as soon as possible postoperatively to minimize the risk for device-associated infections. In a patient with fever and positive blood cultures, the central venous catheter should be removed, and intravenous antibiotics should be started while the final results of the blood cultures are pending.

Postoperative fever is common, and the etiology of the fever varies with the time since the operation. An immediate fever within the first 48 hours after surgery is usually due to cytokine release, transfusion reaction, or drug hypersensitivity. Within the first week, infections are common, especially pneumonia and those associated with central venous or urinary catheters. Surgical-site infections often occur more than a week after surgery, as can infection with Clostridioides difficile, venous thromboembolism, and late-onset central venous catheter-associated infections.

Key learning point: In a patient with a central venous catheter who develops fever and positive blood cultures, the central venous catheter should be removed, if possible.

B) INCORRECT:

A stool sample for Clostridioides difficile is not indicated in the absence of diarrhea, abdominal pain, or leukocytosis.

C) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast is not indicated at this point because a line-related infection is more likely in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Lower-extremity ultrasound and CT of the chest would be used to diagnose deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolus. Although this patient is at risk for both of those conditions, the positive blood cultures point toward a line-related infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Lower-extremity ultrasound and CT of the chest would be used to diagnose deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolus. Although this patient is at risk for both of those conditions, the positive blood cultures point toward a line-related infection.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman receiving chemotherapy for metastatic breast cancer presents to the ED with fever and rigors for two days. She denies cough, headache, abdominal pain, or dysuria. She has a right anterior chest port-a-cath for chemotherapy, which is tender to palpation, although the overlying skin appears normal. Vital signs are BP, 100/64 mm Hg; P, 118; R, 22; T, 38.9°C (102°F); SpO₂, 97% on room air. Laboratory results show WBC 2.4 ×10³/mm³ (normal 3.2–9.8 ×10³/mm³), lactate 2.3 mmol/L, creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, and normal liver enzymes. Urinalysis reveals 5–10 WBC/hpf, trace leukocyte esterase, and no nitrites. Chest x-ray is clear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain peripheral blood cultures, begin IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, and consult for port removal
Perform a lumbar puncture followed by broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
Obtain paired blood cultures from the port and a peripheral vein and initiate broad-spectrum IV antibiotics
Send urine culture and start IV ceftriaxone
Start IV antibiotics and obtain echocardiography to evaluate for endocarditis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this approach appropriately includes empiric antibiotics and source control, omitting cultures from the port limits diagnostic accuracy. Paired blood cultures from the device and a peripheral vein are essential to confirm catheter-related infection through differential time-to-positivity.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence of central nervous system infection: no headache, neck stiffness, or altered mental status. Pursuing lumbar puncture introduces unnecessary delay and procedural risk while failing to address the most probable infectious source.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — Even with a normal overlying skin exam, intraluminal infection remains the most likely suspect of this unexplained fever and pain over her port site. Paired blood cultures provide diagnostic confirmation, and empiric IV antibiotics with early consideration for device removal are indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Trace pyuria without nitrites or urinary symptoms does not confirm a urinary source. In an immunocompromised patient with an indwelling vascular device, attributing fever to a presumed UTI risks missing a catheter-associated bloodstream infection. Hospital admission and broader evaluation are warranted.

E) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics are reasonable in a hemodynamically stable, febrile, immunocompromised patient, but further targeted evaluation, including appropriate cultures, should precede advanced imaging for endocarditis. This approach risks overlooking a more common and accessible infectious source.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with hematologic malignancy is admitted to the ICU with fever and hypotension. She has a femoral central venous catheter placed 3 days ago for chemotherapy administration. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 112; R, 22; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F). The catheter insertion site shows mild erythema without exudate. Blood cultures are drawn from peripheral venipuncture and catheter lumen simultaneously. What additional coverage should be included in the empiric antibiotic regimen beyond gram-positive coverage?

choices.text: Gram-negative bacilli only
Candida species only
Mycobacteria only
No additional coverage needed
Gram-negative bacilli and Candida species

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While gram-negative coverage is indicated based on the location of the catheter, patients with hematologic malignancy are at high risk for fungal infections and require additional antifungal coverage for Candida species.

B) INCORRECT:

Candida coverage is indicated for patients with hematologic malignancy, but patients with femoral catheters also require gram-negative coverage, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycobacteria are not part of routine empiric coverage for catheter-related bloodstream infections. The common pathogens are gram-positive cocci, gram-negative bacilli, and Candida species.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient requires additional coverage beyond gram-positive antibiotics based on location of the catheter and underlying hematologic malignancy, both of which are specific risk factors requiring broader pathogen coverage.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Patients with femoral catheters require empiric coverage for gram-positive pathogens, gram-negative bacilli, and Candida species. Additionally, this patient has hematologic malignancy, which is a specific risk factor requiring antifungal coverage with echinocandins or fluconazole.

Despite high numbers of hand hygiene stations and visual reminders at hospitals, the level of hand hygiene compliance among HCPs remains low because of lapses (due to work overload), poor situational awareness, and/or intolerance or aversion to certain disinfectants. An effective measure to increase compliance is a real-time feedback loop, in which hand hygiene observers or electronic hand hygiene systems monitor compliance and provide immediate feedback (e.g., verbal feedback on improper technique, data visualization of each hospital floor's hand hygiene process measures). Additional steps to increase hand hygiene compliance include staff training and providing alcohol-based foam rubs (which are quicker to use, more effective, and no more irritating to the skin than soap and water) at hand hygiene stations.

CLABSI bundles (a collection of measures to prevent CLABSI) include proper site identification and technique for CVC insertion (e.g., avoiding the femoral region whenever possible), standardized checklists, and aseptic precautions (e.g., sterile glove use, disinfection with chlorhexidine) for CVC insertion as well as CVC site care, CVC removal as soon as possible, and champions-led rounding. These measures are important adjuncts but not substitutes for hand hygiene.

Key learning point: Strict hand hygiene with real-time compliance feedback is the most effective strategy to prevent central-line-associated bloodstream infections.

Use the elbow to dispense disinfectant into the hand, then rub it with the other hand for ∼ 30 seconds. If the hands become dry before this time, dispense more disinfectant.

1. To cover palms, dorsal hands, and web spaces: palm-to-palm and dorsal hands-to-palm, both with fingers together and with fingers interlocked

2. To cover fingers and fingertips: dorsal fingers to opposite palm with fingers interlocked, and rotation of clasped fingers in opposite palm

3. To cover thumbs: rotation of thumb in opposite palm
questions.hint: The onset of fever and hemodynamic instability ≥ 48 hours after the insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) and the growth of the same organism on blood cultures from the CVC and a peripheral vein with a differential time to positivity ≥ 120 minutes indicate a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacillus that causes CLABSI.
